unnormalised: ## The Perils of Predicting Diwali: A Guide for the Chronologically Challenged
normalised: ## The Perils of Predicting Diwali: A Guide for the Chronologically Challenged

unnormalised: So, you want to know when Diwali is this year, huh? Good luck with that. It’s like trying to herd cats wearing sarees while juggling mithai. Predicting the date is a cosmic guessing game, folks. One wrong look at the lunar calendar and you'll be telling everyone to light their diyas on 14/Nov instead of 4/Nov and causing a national chaos. Trust me, your WhatsApp groups will never forgive you. My Auntie Sarla still brings up the great Diwali-fail of '08 at every family gathering. It involved fireworks, a rogue cow, and a very confused pandit.
normalised: So, you want to know when Diwali is this year, huh? Good luck with that. It's like trying to herd cats wearing sarees while juggling mithai. Predicting the date is a cosmic guessing game, folks. One wrong look at the lunar calendar and you'll be telling everyone to light their diyas on fourteenth november instead of fourth november and causing a national chaos. Trust me, your W-h-a-t-s-A-p-p groups will never forgive you. My Auntie Sarla still brings up the great Diwali-fail of zero eight at every family gathering. It involved fireworks, a rogue cow, and a very confused pandit.

unnormalised: The problem isn't just remembering the date itself, which by the way, is tied to the Hindu lunar calendar – a system so complex it makes rocket science look like counting on your fingers (all ten of them, naturally). It's the relentless preponing. "Diwali is fast approaching!" they say, as early as August. Before you can say "Happy Ganesh Chaturthi!" your inbox is flooded with "Diwali Dhamaka!" offers. By 15/Sept, the pressure is on to book your train tickets home, even though the festival itself might be weeks away. Honestly, sometimes it feels like Diwali lasts from September 1st to December 31st!

unnormalised: And let’s not forget the astrologers. Every channel has a ‘Diwali Special’ with some guru predicting your future based on when you decide to burst crackers. They’ll tell you if lighting a sparkler at exactly 7:17 PM on Diwali day will bring you wealth, health, and a promotion. If you light it at 7:18 PM, however, you’re doomed to a life of debt, disease, and having to listen to your neighbour’s bhajan music at 5:00 AM every morning. Tread carefully, my friends.

Tread carefully, my friends.

unnormalised: Then there’s the debate about the actual day to celebrate. Dhanteras on 01/Nov, Choti Diwali on 03/Nov and Badi Diwali on 04/Nov - keep track of all these! It's a minefield. You've got your purists who follow every little ritual down to the last sesame seed and your modernists who just want to light a few anaars and call it a day. There's always *that* uncle who argues that Diwali should *always* be celebrated on the Amavasya tithi, regardless of what the printed calendar says. Just smile, nod, and offer him some more barfi before he starts a family feud that lasts till Holi.

unnormalised: So, how do you survive the Diwali date dilemma? Embrace the chaos! Book your tickets way too early. Buy sweets that are guaranteed to expire before the actual day. And most importantly, blame Google Calendar if you get the date wrong. "Sorry, everyone! The internet told me it was on 25/Oct!" Works every time...ish. Happy Diwali, whenever it actually is!
